prompt_update: You will receive a text. Your task is to continue this text. Just output your new text, nothing else. Here is the text:
initial_story:
The National Police Air Service has shared a video of what it was like flying through Storm Gerrit's heavy winds, in a helicopter.

The footage, which was captured from inside the cockpit, shows the chopper rocking side to side, after being hit by winds of up to 80mph (128km/h).

Posting on X, formerly known as Twitter, the NPAS said "If you think it's windy down there, spare a thought for us up here in our flying washing machine".

The footage was filmed near Lea Valley reservoirs, North London.
stories: The video shows the pilot's hands gripping the controls tightly as the helicopter struggles to maintain its course, with the wind buffeting the aircraft from all sides. At one point, the helicopter dips sharply, throwing the pilot's head against the canopy, and the sound of the rotors roaring in protest can be heard loud and clear.

The pilot's voice comes over the intercom, strained and urgent, as he fights to regain control, his words distorted by the din of the engines and the howling wind. "We're going to crash, I can feel it!" he shouts, his words sending a chill down the spines of those watching from the ground.
"Everyone, get away from the plane, NOW!" someone yells back, and the ground crew scatters, shouting and screaming as they flee from the rapidly deteriorating situation.

The sound of shattering glass and crunching metal filled the air as the plane's engines roared to life, its wheels screeching as it began to move, heading straight for the terminal building with no intention of stopping.

Panic set in as passengers screamed and ran for their lives, but it was too late, the plane had already burst through the terminal doors, sending shards of concrete and steel flying everywhere, as it continued its deadly trajectory through the crowded airport.

The massive aircraft, its engines roaring like beasts, careened wildly down the concourse, crushing everything in its path, as people desperately tried to get out of its way, but many were too slow, too slow to escape the inevitable, as the plane's landing gear screeched and scraped against the ground, sending sparks flying in all directions, and the sound of shattering glass and splintering wood filled the air.

The impact was immense, the plane's fuselage buckling and twisting, its metal skin ripping open like a can of sardines, as the screams of the terrified passengers mingled with the cacophony of crunching metal and snapping glass, and the air was thick with the acrid smell of smoke and burning rubber, as the survivors stumbled out of the wreckage, dazed and disoriented, their faces etched with shock and horror, as the scene of destruction unfolded before their eyes like a gruesome tableau, and the world around them seemed to have come to a standstill.

The chaos was palpable as the survivors stumbled through the wreckage, their screams and cries for help echoing through the stillness, as the sounds of sirens and ambulances grew louder in the distance, and the smell of smoke and burning rubber hung heavy in the air, as the wreckage itself seemed to writhe and twist, like a living thing in agony, and the once-blue sky above was now a deep, foreboding grey, as if the very heavens themselves were mourning the loss, and the survivors' eyes were fixed on the horror before them, their minds reeling in shock and disbelief, as they struggled to comprehend the scale of the destruction, and the impossible task of making sense of the senseless.

As they gazed upon the ruins, the survivors' faces contorted in a mix of grief, guilt, and terror, their minds racing with the what-ifs and the whys, their bodies trembling with the aftershocks of the disaster, their ears still ringing with the cacophony of screams and shattering glass, their nostrils filled with the acrid smell of smoke and burning flesh, and their hearts heavy with the weight of unimaginable loss, as the sirens grew louder and the ambulances drew near, their bright lights and wailing horns a stark contrast to the darkness and desolation that surrounded them, and the survivors' thoughts turned to the loved ones they had lost, their memories flooding back in a torrent of emotions, as they struggled to come to terms with the new reality, and the daunting task of rebuilding and healing lay ahead.

As they stood there, frozen in shock and despair, the survivors' eyes were drawn to the figure of a young girl, no more than ten years old, who lay motionless on the ground, her small body twisted at an unnatural angle, her bright blue eyes frozen in a permanent stare, her tiny hands clutching a torn and bloodied stuffed animal, as if she was holding onto the last shred of comfort in a world that had been turned upside down, and the survivors' minds recoiled in horror at the thought of the life that had been so brutally and senselessly cut short, and the weight of their grief threatened to crush them, as they wondered what kind of evil could have led to this, and how they would ever be able to move on from this unspeakable tragedy.

The sound of her ragged breathing was the only thing that broke the silence, and even that seemed to be the only thing holding back the overwhelming sense of devastation that threatened to consume them all, as they struggled to comprehend the magnitude of the destruction that had been wrought, and the survivors' eyes welled up with tears as they gazed upon the tiny, lifeless form, their hearts heavy with the knowledge that they would never hear her laughter, never see her smile, never feel her small hand in theirs, and the weight of their collective grief became almost too much to bear, as they realized that this was not just the loss of a child, but the destruction of a future, a family, a community, and a world that would never be the same again.

As they stood there, frozen in shock and sorrow, the warm sun beating down on them, the air thick with the acrid smell of smoke and ash, a sense of numbness began to creep over them, a numbing agent to dull the pain, but even that seemed a cruel joke, for in the silence, they could still hear her tiny voice, whispering sweet nothings, her giggles, her coos, her innocent questions, and it was as if she was still there, still alive, still full of life, and the ache in their chests grew, a heavy, crushing weight that threatened to suffocate them, as they struggled to come to terms with the fact that she was gone, and the world was forever changed.

The memories of her bright smile, her sparkling eyes, her tiny hand holding theirs, flooded back, and with them, the bitter taste of grief. They felt like they were drowning in a sea of tears, their lungs burning from the effort of taking each ragged breath. The sun, which had once shone so brightly, now seemed distant and cold, a cruel reminder of the beauty and joy that had been taken from them.

As they stood there, frozen in time, the world around them began to blur and fade, replaced by the haunting echo of her laughter, the soft whisper of her name, and the desperate longing to turn back the clock, to hold her close one more time, to tell her how much they loved her, to beg her to stay.

But the clock ticked on, merciless and unforgiving, as the memories of their past together grew hazy and indistinct, like the edges of a watercolor painting left too long in the rain, and the silence that followed her departure grew thicker and more oppressive, until it seemed to suffocate them, a heavy shroud that choked the very breath from their lungs.

As they sat in the darkness, the only sound the soft ticking of the clock, they both knew that the silence was not just a pause between words, but a chasm that had grown wider with each passing day, a gulf that seemed to stretch between them like an endless, desolate landscape, devoid of even a single strand of hope.

The air was heavy with the weight of unspoken words, the tension between them palpable as a living thing, and yet they dared not speak, for fear of shattering the fragile calm that had settled over their lives like a shroud, and plunging them into the abyss of recrimination and regret.

As they sat there, frozen in a tableau of unease, the clock on the wall ticked away with an infuriating slowness, its steady beat a reminder that time was running out, and that the silence between them was slowly suffocating them, choking off the very breath from their lungs.

The air was heavy with unspoken words, a thick fog that clung to their skin like a damp shroud, making every breath feel like a struggle, every glance a betrayal. The shadows on the wall seemed to deepen, to grow longer and darker, as if they too were aware of the tension that had built between them, and were feeding off it, growing stronger with every passing moment.

Their eyes met, and for a moment, they just stared, the silence between them a living, breathing thing that pulsed with the weight of all the unspoken words. Then, without a word, she turned and walked away, leaving him standing there, feeling the sting of her rejection like a physical blow.

He watched her go, his eyes burning with a mix of frustration and longing, as he wondered what he had done to deserve such a cold shoulder. The sound of her footsteps echoed through the empty hallway, growing fainter with each passing second, until he was left standing alone in the silence, the weight of their unspoken words settling around him like a shroud.

He took a deep breath, the cool air filling his lungs, and slowly let it out, trying to shake off the sense of unease that had settled in the pit of his stomach. He glanced around the deserted hallway, the dim lighting making the shadows seem to writhe and twist on the walls, and felt a shiver run down his spine.

As he stood there, the silence was oppressive, punctuated only by the soft creaks and groans of the old building, and he couldn't shake the feeling that he was being watched. He rubbed his arms, trying to generate some warmth, and took another step forward, his eyes scanning the dark corners of the hallway. Suddenly, he stopped, his heart racing, as he thought he saw a faint movement out of the corner of his eye.

He spun around, his eyes darting wildly across the hallway, but there was nothing there. He took a deep breath, trying to calm himself down, but his heart was still racing. He thought he heard a faint whisper, a soft rustling of fabric, and he felt a shiver run down his spine. He took another step forward, his eyes fixed on the spot where he thought he saw the movement, and that was when he saw her.

Her long, dark hair seemed to blend seamlessly into the shadows, and her eyes gleamed like emeralds in the dim light. She didn't seem to be moving, but he could have sworn he saw her lips curve into a faint, enigmatic smile. He felt a chill run down his spine as she began to move towards him, her steps silent as a ghost's.

As she drew closer, the air around her seemed to thicken, like a palpable mist that clung to her like a shroud. Her eyes never left his, and he could feel their weight, like a gentle pressure on his skin. He tried to take a step back, but his feet seemed rooted to the spot, unable to move as she loomed over him, her smile growing wider, more sinister.

The sound of her voice was like a cold breeze on a winter's night, sending shivers down his spine as she whispered his name, the syllables dripping with malice and intent. Her eyes gleamed with an unholy light, as if the very darkness itself had taken on a life of its own, and was now consuming him whole. He tried to speak, to beg for mercy, but his voice was trapped in his throat, refusing to emerge as she leaned in, her hot breath washing over him like a wave of despair.

As she drew closer, her lips inches from his ear, he could feel her warm breath caressing his skin, sending shivers of fear racing down his spine. He tried to turn away, to escape her grasp, but her grip was like a vice, holding him fast as she whispered a single word in his ear: "Mine."

The sound of her voice sent a chill through him, and he felt his heart racing in his chest as he struggled to free himself from her grasp. But she held him firm, her fingers digging deep into his skin as she leaned in closer, her breath hot against his ear. "You know I mean it," she hissed, her voice low and menacing. "You're mine now, and you'll never be free again."

As he tried to process her words, he felt a cold sweat break out on his forehead, and his vision began to blur at the edges. He knew he had to think fast, or he'd be trapped forever, at her mercy. He strained against her grip, trying to twist his arm free, but she held him like a vice, her strength surprising him. Suddenly, he remembered the small object in his pocket, a tiny device that could be his only hope. With a surge of adrenaline, he reached for it, his heart pounding in his chest.

His fingers closed around the small device, and he quickly pressed the button, feeling a rush of relief as he heard the soft beep of the alarm being triggered. He knew it was a long shot, but it was his only chance. He began to struggle again, this time more desperately, hoping to break free before she realized what was happening.

His arms and legs flailed wildly, but she was too strong, her grip like a vice around his wrists and ankles. He felt a surge of panic as he realized he wasn't going to be able to escape, and his eyes met hers, pleading for help. But she just smiled, her eyes glinting with a sinister light, and leaned in closer.

As she leaned in, her hot breath whispered against his ear, sending shivers down his spine, and he could feel her warm breath tickling the hairs on the back of his neck. Her voice was low and husky, sending a chill down his spine, as she whispered a single word: "Mine."

His eyes fluttered closed, his heart racing with anticipation, as he felt her lips brush against his earlobe, sending a wave of desire coursing through his veins. He knew in that moment, he was hers, and she was his, forever bound by the promise of that one word.
The whispered promise echoed in his mind, a sweet melody that only she knew the tune to, as he wrapped his arms around her waist, pulling her closer to him.

As he leaned in to whisper the words in her ear, the moonlight dancing across her face seemed to intensify, illuminating the soft curve of her cheek and the gentle flutter of her eyelashes, and he felt his heart beat in time with the rhythm of his own pulse.

The sweet scent of her perfume wafted up to him, transporting him back to the first night they met, when the same moon hung low in the sky and the same spark of attraction had crackled between them, leaving him breathless and yearning for more.

He closed his eyes, the memory flooding his senses, and when he opened them again, she was standing right in front of him, her eyes shining with a knowing light, as if she had been conjured up by his own longing. "You've been thinking about that night, haven't you?" she whispered, her voice like a gentle breeze on a summer's day.

Her words sent a shiver down his spine, and he nodded slowly, his eyes never leaving hers. "How did you know?" he asked, his voice barely above a whisper, as if he was afraid to break the spell that had been cast. She smiled, her lips curving upwards, and took a step closer, her hand reaching out to touch the scar above his left eyebrow.

"He was a careless one, your friend," she said, her voice low and husky, her eyes never leaving his. "He didn't understand the power he was playing with. But you... you're different. You sense it, don't you? The way the air seems to vibrate with an otherworldly energy whenever we're together."

"I sense nothing," he lied, his eyes locked on hers, his pulse racing with a mix of excitement and unease, as he wondered what she was getting at. "Just the usual attraction between two people." But her gaze pierced through his denials, and he could feel the weight of her skepticism, like a physical force pressing in on him.

"I'm not talking about attraction," she said, her voice low and even, "although I'm not sure I believe that's all there is to it either. I'm talking about something else. Something you're not telling me."

"What do you mean?" I asked, my mind racing with possibilities, my heart beating just a little bit faster. She leaned in, her eyes locked on mine, and I could feel the air between us grow thick with tension.
"Why would you think something is wrong?" she whispered, her voice low and husky, sending shivers down my spine. "We're just having a conversation, aren't we?"
"But your eyes are telling a different story," I replied, my own voice barely above a whisper, as I leaned in closer to her, my face inches from hers. "What's really going on, Sarah?"

"Nothing," she whispered back, her breath hot against my skin, her eyes darting back and forth between mine, searching for a way out of the trap I had so skillfully set. But I knew her too well, and I could see the flicker of guilt dancing in their depths. "Why do you think something's going on?"

"Because I've been watching you, and I know you're not as innocent as you seem," I said, my voice low and menacing, my eyes locked onto hers as I leaned in closer, my face inches from hers. "You've been sneaking around, talking to people in hushed tones, and I have a feeling you're hiding something big."

"You're right," she whispered, her eyes darting back and forth between mine, a mixture of fear and defiance flashing across her face. "I am hiding something, but you'll never guess what it is. And even if you did, you wouldn't care, would you?"

"I don't know what's going on, but I can see the truth in your eyes," I said, my voice low and even. "Whatever it is, it's eating away at you, and I'm not going to stop until I find out what it is. You can't scare me off with your games, Rachel. I'm not going anywhere until we get to the bottom of this."

"Games?" Rachel's voice was a cold, sweet melody, and it sent a shiver down my spine. "You're the one playing games, Alex. You're trying to manipulate me, to get inside my head. Well, let me tell you something - it's not going to work. I'm not some fragile little thing that can be broken with a few well-placed words. I'm a grown woman, and I know how to take care of myself."
